user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of close_connection:
```c
static void
close_connection (struct MHD_Connection *pos)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = pos->daemon;

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon))
  {
    MHD_connection_mark_closed_ (pos);
    return;   /* must let thread to do the rest */
  }
  MHD_connection_close_ (pos,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_DAEMON_SHUTDOWN);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  mhd_assert (! pos->suspended);
  mhd_assert (! pos->resuming);
  if (pos->connection_timeout_ms == daemon->connection_timeout_ms)
    XDLL_remove (daemon->normal_timeout_head,
                 daemon->normal_timeout_tail,
                 pos);
  else
    XDLL_remove (daemon->manual_timeout_head,
                 daemon->manual_timeout_tail,
                 pos);
  DLL_remove (daemon->connections_head,
              daemon->connections_tail,
              pos);
  DLL_insert (daemon->cleanup_head,
              daemon->cleanup_tail,
              pos);
  daemon->data_already_pending = true;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function close_connection:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected fragments that can lead to code being never executed in some builds or runtime configurations and therefore warrant investigation for MISRA C Rule 2.1. In particular, the early return guarded by MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ can make the remainder of the function unreachable if that condition is effectively always true; conversely the branch body could be unreachable if the condition is always false. The two XDLL_remove branches depend on a runtime equality test that could be constant in some builds, making one branch unreachable. The mutex lock/unlock blocks are conditional on build-time macros and can remove synchronization code paths entirely. The mhd_assert lines are implemented as a no-op macro in the provided definitions; any expressions inside those asserts are therefore not present in the compiled code and should be reviewed to ensure no code was made unreachable or lost as a result.

I did not flag the function signature, the local variable assignment (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = pos->daemon;), the comment lines, or the final assignment to daemon->data_already_pending as suspicious because those pieces are simple, syntactically reachable in at least one execution path, and do not by themselves create unreachable code. Similarly, isolated preprocessor conditionals that only include or exclude bookkeeping lines (but do not introduce unconditional returns) were not flagged unless they bracket code that can make other parts unreachable (as noted above).
